title: How to add my DVD player on my PC - Quora

response.answer_text: Unless you have only an external standalone DVD player with video outputs, you’re MUCH better off using either the internal SATA connections or external USB connections which keep the digital video information intact. Neither of these is expensive these days, and trying to take the video output (composite, component, SVHS or HDMI) into the computer would not only lose video quality, but also cost as much for the external video adapters (typically dongles that attach to USB) that it’d actually be cheaper to just buy a new external USB DVD player/burner. Then you can use Handbrake to copy the DVD, or VLC to play the video files, both freeware (last time I checked) available for many operating systems.

I don’t understand this question? You realize that a “DVD Drive” for a PC is like ~$20 So are you asking about a “stand-alone DVD player?” Why would you buy one of those for a PC? They’re basically a mini PC attached to a DVD drive. Instead, you should get a DVD/Blu-Ray Drive for a PC. They’ve got External USB DVD Burners/Readers for $30. For ~$50 you can get a Bluray Burner that goes in a Standard 5.25″ Drive Bay you can find them on Sites like Amazon, Newegg, etc. The answer is yes it’s possible there are “Video Riping Cards” but you’re far better off just getting a Ripping program (like anydvd) for a backup of your videos on to HDD. Perhaps using a free program like “handbrake” to encode it for whatever device. There is plenty of software out there for this stuff. And just using an inexpensive Blu-Ray/DVD Burner is super easy! Good Luck.
